instructions_en:
Instruct patient:

  1. Take a deep breath.

  2. In your native language, count clearly from 1 to 30 out loud, as fast as possible without stopping, until you are either out of breath or reach 30.

Clinician: Time how many seconds it takes the patient to reach 30, or until they must take another breath.

Also, record the highest number they can reach before they have to take another breath.

before_use:
• This score has been proposed as a gross attempt to suggest hypoxia via voice/telephone, and has not been validated. Launched during COVID-19 crisis. COVID-19 Resource Center.

  • It obviously does not at all substitute for pulse oximetry or an in-person evaluation of a patient, but these are very challenging times and it is difficult to assess hypoxia without exposing healthcare workers to possible COVID, expending PPE, etc.

  • The score is based on only 93 patients being admitted for pulmonary reasons (pneumonia, COPD, CHF, etc).
medium_description_en: Screens for hypoxia in dyspneic patients.

how_to_use.use_case_en: The Roth Score may be useful to grossly screen for hypoxia in patients reporting shortness of breath but when one is unable to safely or easily perform pulse oximetry on the patient.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• This score has not been validated, and was developed on only 93 patients (with control comparisons). 

  • It does not substitute for pulse oximetry, and is far from a perfect tool given its relatively small study size and lack of external validation.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• In the setting of the COVID-19 global pandemic, it is incredibly difficult to maintain self-isolation/quarantine, conserve PPE, and also see patients directly and measure their vital signs (specifically, hypoxia). 

  • While most patients with COVID-19 do not appear to require hospitalization (80% in most studies as of March 2020), about 20% do require hospitalization mainly due to hypoxemic respiratory failure, pneumonia, and ARDS; the most obvious indications for admission being tachypnea and hypoxia. The Roth Score may help suggest hypoxia in the patient who is not obviously tachypneic or does not "sound" particularly ill over the phone.

next_steps.critical_actions_en:
• The Roth Score, if used, should only be one piece of data in a clinician's evaluation of a patient, especially if the initial screening/evaluation is via telephone or even video evaluation.

  • As it is not particularly specific for hypoxia, one should not use it exclusively to decide that a patient requires in-person or emergency evaluation.

about.more_info_en:
Interpretation:

Risk based on maximum number reached before next breath

<10

91% sensitive for O₂ sat <95%

<7

87% sensitive for O₂ sat <90%

>10

Roth score less suggestive of hypoxia (but at higher numbers the score appears to be less sensitive for hypoxia)

Risk based on total seconds counted before next breath

<7

83% sensitive for O₂ sat <95%

<5

82% sensitive for O₂ sat <90%

>7

Roth score less suggestive of hypoxia (but at higher numbers the score appears to be less sensitive for hypoxia)

Note: Medical conditions, overall gestalt, and risk should be taken into consideration by the treating clinician.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Chorin E, Padegimas A, Havakuk O, et al. Assessment of Respiratory Distress by the Roth Score. Clin Cardiol. 2016;39(11):636-639.

creator_info.about_en: Ehud Chorin, MD, PhD, is a physician in the cardiology department at Tel Aviv Medical Center in Israel. Dr. Chorin’s primary research is focused on treatment of coronary heart disease.

expert_name.description: Graham Walker, MD, is an emergency physician practicing in San Francisco, California. Dr. Walker attended medical school at the Stanford University School of Medicine and then trained in emergency medicine at St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York City, where he was Chief Resident. He returned to the west coast as a Medical Simulation fellow and attending in Stanford’s emergency department. More relevant, of course, is that Dr. Walker is the creator and developer of MDCalc and remains active in content and calculator development, along with our many other endeavors as President of MD Aware, LLC (MDCalc’s parent company).
